body.p: Isis to RC i have been indulging in a naivety of feelings since your letter came to hand; some of which were in some degree painful, and others were of a more pleasing cast: the painful ones, arise in a great degree from the insinuations held out by others[?] and in so offensive a manner communicated to you; I must to day command him to speak out. 'tis no trifling subject: if I, or any other person [with] whom you are surrounded[?], are really acting unjustly toward you, tis fitting you should know it, and the sooner, the better. when Thomas[?], so insulting told me that he would do me all the injury he possibly could, i thought he meant in relation, to an attachment, which my conduct, has led him to discover, I much fear, too easily. I feel a conscious rectitude of purpose, and intention in every transaction, that, as far, as my feeble endeavours would allow, i have served you; at least, in every instance, my wish was, to do you all the good I could. if a sincere regard for your person and manners: If a reverence, and respect, for your sufferings; If admiration, of your political character: If respect for your intellectual attainments: If an endeav[our] to imitate your virtuous example, your nob[le?] conduct: If an anxiety, for your future welfare[:] If a desire to serve, to assist, to comfort, to contribute to your happiness: If a love, as ardent, as pure, as tender, as true and as disinterested, has ever warmed a woman's heart: If I say, sentiments, such as are [[2]] here expressed, be acts of injustice, I plead guilty in every sense of the word: but, in a contrary point of view, I reject, with scorn, with ineffable contempt the accusation. Do not suffer a thought detrimental to our peace, to intrude in your bosom, which i wish, only to be the seat of rest. Believe me [in] saying, that i have ever had, since i have [kn]own you, your interest, and happiness, at heart. I am sincerely attached to you and during our twenty years connexion, you will even find me acting according to your circumstances; to do well for you, will be doing well for myself. And in whatever circumstances we are placed, you shall ever find me cheerful, placid, and agreeable; happy in your love, secure in your regard; and aiming to be everything you wish me to be, "an highly gifted intellectual woman," Think no more of what Thomas [?] has said, which I declare him to be a rascal toward me and you particularly: place reliance upon my affection, and when, an anxious wish to please and to act honorably toward you, whom I prefer to all [th]e world; Do not injure yourself, and me by a suspicion, unworthy of both. In deviating the remainder of my life to your service, I shall act, in accordance with my feelings and desires, I never wish to leave you, and hope always to be near you, Never to part until we are divided by death.
